content: The Act may be cited as the "Tribal Tax and Investment Reform Act of 2016". The Congress recognizes the unique legal and political relationship between the United States and Indian tribes. Indian tribes have the authority to provide governmental programs, develop economies, and build infrastructure on reservation lands. Federal laws and regulations acknowledge Indian tribes as governments. Indian tribes have the authority to develop economies, build infrastructure, and provide governmental programs on reservation lands. Federal laws recognize tribes as governments, allowing them to finance projects with government bonds and maintain tax exemptions. Indian tribes have the authority to tax, operate like other governments, finance projects with government bonds, and maintain tax exemptions. Codifying tax parity with tribal governments aligns with Federal treaties recognizing tribal sovereignty and addresses historic disadvantages in accessing capital for infrastructure development. Indian tribes face historic disadvantages in accessing capital for infrastructure development and are sometimes excluded from key provisions in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, resulting in unfair tax treatment. Restrictions on tribal governance hinder economic development. Indian tribes are excluded from key provisions in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, leading to unfair tax treatment. Congress regulates commerce with tribes to promote self-governance and affirm the government-to-government relationship. Indian tribes are treated as states for bond issuance. Indian tribal governments are treated as states for certain tax-exempt bond purposes, with special rules for bond issuance based on national tribal population estimates. The Secretary of the Treasury establishes a national bond volume cap annually based on State population and minimum State ceiling amounts, allocating it among all entities. The national bond volume cap is established annually by the Secretary of the Treasury based on State population and minimum State ceiling amounts, and is allocated among all Indian tribal governments seeking an allocation.
